text: mr. president my fourth and final term
is a united states senator will soon
come to an end 40 years in elective
office 24 in the Senate I definitely
feel like it's the right decision I made
not to run again and it's the right time
to leave I wanted to leave when I could
leave unless courted how much you think
about 2000 and what might have been when
I look back to it the first emotion I
have honestly and if this gets deeper
and deeper as time goes on his gratitude
to Al Gore you know I'm grateful to him
that he chose me that he took a risk
breaking a barrier first American Jewish
American to run in a national ticket and
his confidence was vindicated really in
America every anytime I look back at it
of course I'm I'm you know disappointed
frustrated angry and how it ended
because I think Al Gore and I could have
given the country great leadership and
really because of how it ended not with
counting the votes really but with a
five-to-four Supreme Court decision that
in my opinion had little or no basis in
Supreme Court precedent really in some
ways I think if you think about it my
most productive 12 years in the Senate
were in the 12 years since 2000 what
after all is a Democrat like me doing at
a republican convention like this and I
don't have any regrets about speaking at
the convention I know was unconventional
so to speak say the obvious I was still
not the most popular person in the
Democratic Party because of my support
for the Iraq war but you know I didn't
go i went to the convention to speak to
make an affirmative statement about John
McCain my friend who I believed was was
prepared to be a strong president but if
I had it to do over again I would have
said nothing about barack obama i would
say that where the president i remained
friends i mean i've obviously disagreed
with them on some foreign policy things
but you look back at the first term i I
was in the middle of helping him to pass
his two major domestic accompli
well three really one being the stimulus
legislation in 2009 and then the health
care reform bill at the end of two
thousand and finally and this one I was
really at the lead of the repeal of
Don't Ask Don't Tell throughout my 24
years here I mean that I've had the
chance to be involved in some
legislative accomplishments that I'm
really proud of and environmentally
human rights foreign policy national
security homeland security every one of
them was accomplished because it had
bipartisan support this problem of
partisan polarization ideological
rigidity which has made our government
in Washington dysfunctional this is not
the fault of one party by any means and
you can see it now in in the what
appears to be again the gridlock over an
agreement to avoid the country going
over the fiscal cliff if you began in
politics today would you be a Democrat
Republican or an independent wow I would
guess most Americans or at least a
plurality of Americans that neither
party quite it fits the full range of my
views I seem to fall always right within
the 45 2 45 yard line so I'm probably a
centrist notwithstanding the fact that
unaffiliated voters independent voters
are the fastest growing group in
American politics still if you want to
make your way into politics you got to
join a party
